'''Women Surrealists''' are women [[artists]], [[photographers]], [[filmmakers]] and [[authors]] of the [[Surrealism|Surrealist]] Movement which began in the early 1920s. Many of them were part of, or connected to, the official [[Surrealist]] movement. Others were inspired but more distantly connected.
==Painters== *[[Eileen Forrester Agar]] (1899â1991) was born in Argentina and moved to [[United Kingdom|Britain]] in childhood. She was prominent among British surrealists; Agar made intricate collages and paintings of abstract organic shapes.<ref name=Colvile>Colvile, Georgiana, ''Scandaleusement d'elles: trente-quatre femmes surrÃ©alistes'', Jean-Michel Place, Paris, 1999 ISBN 978-2858934966</ref>
*[[Leonora Carrington]] (1917-2011) was a British-born Surrealist painter. She met the Surrealist [[Max Ernst]] in 1937, and had a painful and complicated relationship with him. Much of her work is autobiographical.<ref name=Heller />.
*[[Leonor Fini]] (1907â1996), born in [[Buenos Aires]] and raised in [[Trieste]], met the Surrealists in 1936 but never officially joined. She paints startling images, often with [[sphinxes]] or apparitions.<ref name=Heller/>
*[[Kay Sage]] (1898â1963) began painting surrealist landscapes in the late 1930s, met and married fellow surrealist[[Yves Tanguy]] in 1940.<ref name=Heller>Heller, Nancy G., ''Women Artists: An Illustrated History'', Abbeville Press, Publishers, New York 1987 ISBN 0-89659-748-2</ref>
*[[Dorothea Tanning]] (born 1910) was unable to join the Surrealists in Paris in 1940 because of the threat of war; she worked in New York, Arizona, and then Paris after the war. Her work has a rumpled, "juicy" look.<ref name=Heller />
*[[Remedios Varo]] (1908â1963), a Spaniard who moved to Mexico, was known for her dreamlike paintings of scientific apparatus. She was married to the Surrealist poet [[Benjamin Peret]].<ref name=Heller /><ref name=Kaplan>Kaplan, Janet A. ''Unexpected Journeys: The Art and Life of Remedios Varo'', Abbeville Press, New York 1988 ISBN 0-89659-797-0</ref>
*[[Gertrude Abercrombie]] (1909â1977) was a [[Chicago]] artist inspired by the Surrealists, who became prominent in the 1930s and 1940s. She was also involved with the [[jazz]] music scene and was friends with musicians such as [[Dizzy Gillespie]], [[Charlie Parker]], and [[Sarah Vaughan]].<ref name=Vine>Richard Vine, "[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1248/is_/ai_19385182 Where the Wild Things Were]", ''[[Art in America]]'', May 1997, pp. 98-111</ref><ref name=Warren>Warren, Lynn, ''Art in Chicago 1945-1995'', Thames & Hudson, 1996 ISBN 978-0500237281</ref>
==Sculptors== *[[MÃ©ret Oppenheim]] (1913â1985) was a German-Swiss sculptor, famous as one of [[Man Ray]]'s models. Her most famous sculpture is ''[[Object (Le DÃ©jeuner en fourrure)|Object (Breakfast in Fur)]]'', a teacup, saucer and spoon completely encased in soft brown fur.<ref name=Heller/>
==Photographers== *[[Claude Cahun]] (1894-1954) was a French photographer and writer, associated with the surrealist movement. *[[Lee Miller]] (1907-1977) was an American photographer, photojournalist and model.
